text:
key selling arguments - mod harbour
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
How are you going to make things easy?
How are you going to save them time?
 How are you going to save them money?

As marketers, dbf-support is the unique selling point for mod harbour!
And with a mapped drive, you have a power solution.
You can access your remote files as if it is on your local disk using Windows Explorer, macOS Finder, and all of your software.
No need for myPHPAdmin! - you work with your familiar dBase editor.

You can work with your desktop program, like in the local network.

elements.text:
key selling arguments - mod harbour
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
How are you going to make things easy?
How are you going to save them time?
 How are you going to save them money?

As marketers, dbf-support is the unique selling point for mod harbour!
And with a mapped drive, you have a power solution.
You can access your remote files as if it is on your local disk using Windows Explorer, macOS Finder, and all of your software.
No need for myPHPAdmin! - you work with your familiar dBase editor.

You can work with your desktop program, like in the local network.

text: I have concerns about manually editing the same database that is in production

elements.text: I have concerns about manually editing the same database that is in production

text: Though I do find myself having to do that many times.

elements.text: Though I do find myself having to do that many times.

text: Also, I'm not sure how well do dbf's handle concurrent access while editing. Are transactions atomic?

elements.text: Also, I'm not sure how well do dbf's handle concurrent access while editing. Are transactions atomic?

text:
We desktop developers have to do that every day, that's our daily bread.
Even a heart specialist has to work with an open heart.

text:
Desktop programs and a certain amount of customers is a totally different job.
I don't think there are many here who are familiar with these everyday problems.

elements.text:
Desktop programs and a certain amount of customers is a totally different job.

text:
In this SLACK discussion, we should introduce different programming classes.
I represent, for example. the type:
• a small software house that deals with the sale of its programs
• about product development
• the right hardware
• to train users 
• daily support  24 hours
• business plan for the own company
• finding employees
• to finance leasing for customers
and take care of a lot more.

text:
It is essential for the discussion here that you are primarily a web programmer, for example.
So the others can value the arguments.
As I said, the main focus of my company is at the moment desktop but also to offer in future online solutions.
But we have to stay compatible.

elements.text:
It is essential for the discussion here that you are primarily a web programmer, for example.
So the others can value the arguments.
As I said, the main focus of my company is at the moment desktop but also to offer in future online solutions.

What I wanted to say is that it would be nice if everyone could tell us what they wanted to do with mod harbor.
For example, some are here because they like building mod harbour it self, others need mod harbour for there personal work, others see business opportunities and so on.

text:
Before mod harbour, I started a project with Symfony.

It is true that PHP becomes confusing for larger projects without a framework.

That's why a framework is needed.

A framework in dBase style is sure to be a success, just like dBase itself back then.

GENESIS and Beacon are precisely right here.

elements.text:
Before mod harbour, I started a project with Symfony.

It is true that PHP becomes confusing for larger projects without a framework.

That's why a framework is needed.

A framework in dBase style is sure to be a success, just like dBase itself back then.

GENESIS and Beacon are precisely right here.

text:
I'm so excited.
A mapped drive, DBF files, a dbf-editor, and a mod harbor web page have the potential to attack WORDPRESS.
Data maintenance with the dbf editor is simple and ingenious and, above all, fast. No overhead.
No learning curve.

No learning curve.

De momento está como una página de recursos con enlaces, y además tú tienes permisos de admin en todos los repositorios de <https://github.com/mod-harbour>
Hay que organizarlo para que no parezca que va cada uno por su lado porque la idea es hacer las cosas fáciles para el que venga nuevo.

text: Ese fue exactamente el tema de la charla del viernes. Github no se actualiza porque Antonio no lo hace ni da acceso a nadie para que lo haga. Si nadie lo hace, entonces cómo se va a poder integrar la web en gitub ? Es claramente una situacion catch22.  Puedes clonar la web de la org y meterla tal cual está o modificada en el github cuando gustes. El fin de la org es ayudar a la comunidad y orientar a usuarios nuevos o con poca experiencia. En la pagina habrá links a todos los ejemplos que ayuden a la gente a desarrollar producos web. HGMWEB esta en modo demo online y sus fuentes publicados con licencia libre, autorizado por su autor original. Cuando génesis disponga de un demo activo se repondrá el link a él. También se incluirá todo producto que sirva para difundir las capacidades de mod_harbour sea comercial o freeware, de codigo cerrdo o abierto, cuyo autor así lo desee y la org considere util a los fines de difusion de mod_harbour como concepto.

text: hb_threadStart() está devolviendo nil

text: Esto funciona bien en Linux:

elements.text: Esto funciona bien en Linux:

text:
function Main()

   local pThread := hb_ThreadStart( @Another() )

   if hb_threadWait( pThread, 15 ) != 1
      hb_threadQuitRequest( pThread )
   endif

   ? "salida estandard"

return nil

function Another()

   ? "Desde another"

return nil

elements.text:
function Main()

   local pThread := hb_ThreadStart( @Another() )

   if hb_threadWait( pThread, 15 ) != 1
      hb_threadQuitRequest( pThread )
   endif

   ? "salida estandard"

return nil

function Another()

   ? "Desde another"

return nil

text: Para exportar todos los símbolos de la DLL en Linux, usamos el fichero libs.txt ó no hay forma de pasar el parámetro -Wl,--whole-archive, ya que este flag tiene que cerrarse con -Wl,--no-whole-archive

elements.text: Para exportar todos los símbolos de la DLL en Linux, usamos el fichero libs.txt ó no hay forma de pasar el parámetro -Wl,--whole-archive, ya que este flag tiene que cerrarse con -Wl,--no-whole-archive

text: Este código SIN mod_harbour funciona bien en Windows y falla en Linux:

elements.text: Este código SIN mod_harbour funciona bien en Windows y falla en Linux:

text:
function Main()

   local pThread := hb_ThreadStart( @Another() )

   if hb_threadWait( pThread, 15 ) != 1
      hb_threadQuitRequest( pThread )
   endif

   ? "standard exit"

return nil

function Another()

   ? ValType( hb_ThreadStart( @OneMore() ) )

   ? "From another"

return nil

function OneMore()

   ? "from OneMore"

return nil

elements.text:

   local pThread := hb_ThreadStart( @Another() )

   if hb_threadWait( pThread, 15 ) != 1
      hb_threadQuitRequest( pThread )
   endif

   ? "standard exit"

return nil

function Another()

   ? ValType( hb_ThreadStart( @OneMore() ) )

   ? "From another"

return nil

function OneMore()

   ? "from OneMore"

return nil

text:
> O va tan rápido Linux que la app termina antes de que el ultimo thread termine ??
No sé cómo lo estás ejecutando, pero normalmente la salida de los procesos huérfanos te sigue saliendo en la terminal después de que el proceso padre acabe.

elements.text: O va tan rápido Linux que la app termina antes de que el ultimo thread termine ??
